articles.headline: Israel Expands Ground Forces Inside Lebanon
articles.snippet: Israel sent up to 7,000 troops into Lebanon, aimed at pushing Hezbollah back from the border before a cease-fire is declared.
articles.abstract: Israel sent up to 7,000 troops into Lebanon, aimed at pushing Hezbollah back from the border before a cease-fire is declared.
articles.lead_paragraph: MISGAV AM, Israel, Wednesday, Aug. 2 — Israel sent up to 7,000 troops into Lebanon on Tuesday, a significant increase in a ground offensive aimed at pushing the Hezbollah militia back from the border before a cease-fire is declared and a multinational force deployed.
articles.byline: By Craig S. Smith and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Anxiety Rises as Paychecks Trail Inflation
articles.snippet: What do Chicago’s new $10 minimum wage for big-box retailers and Colorado’s new immigration law say about the politics of the economy?
articles.abstract: What do Chicago’s new $10 minimum wage for big-box retailers and Colorado’s new immigration law say about the politics of the economy?
articles.lead_paragraph: LAST week, as the Chicago City Council prepared to vote on a bill that would impose a $10 minimum wage on the city’s big-box retailers by 2010 and require them to pay health benefits as well, the big guns came out to defeat it.

articles.headline: Toyota’s U.S. Sales Edge Past Ford’s
articles.snippet: American buyers are again flocking to Japanese companies in the wake of high gasoline prices.
articles.abstract: American buyers are again flocking to Japanese companies in the wake of high gasoline prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Aug. 1 — The Japanese auto giant Toyota passed the struggling Ford Motor Company in July to rank as the second-biggest-selling auto company in the United States, behind General Motors, sales figures showed Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Fara Warner

articles.headline: Castro Is ‘Stable,’ but His Illness Presents Puzzle
articles.snippet: A statement read on state television after a long day of speculation and rumor gave few details about Fidel Castro's condition.
articles.abstract: A statement read on state television after a long day of speculation and rumor gave few details about Fidel Castro's condition.

articles.headline: Postal Service Finds a Friend in the Internet
articles.snippet: Sites like Amazon.com and eBay are bolstering the number of packages shipped via the Postal Service.
articles.abstract: Sites like Amazon.com and eBay are bolstering the number of packages shipped via the Postal Service.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a recent conference that attracted 15,000 eBay fanatics to Las Vegas, the main sponsor was a big advocate of online shopping: none other than the United States Postal Service.

articles.headline: A New Page in the Script for Paulson
articles.snippet: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. said Tuesday that he recognized the economy was not benefiting all Americans.
articles.abstract: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. said Tuesday that he recognized the economy was not benefiting all Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., delivering his first public remarks since taking office last month, said yesterday that he recognized that the economy was not benefiting all Americans.

articles.headline: These Days, Wall Street Does It All
articles.snippet: In a further illustration of the copycat economics of Wall Street, Lehman Brothers is now raising a private equity fund.
articles.abstract: In a further illustration of the copycat economics of Wall Street, Lehman Brothers is now raising a private equity fund.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Finds That Its Formula Doesn’t Fit Every Culture
articles.snippet: Given Wal-Mart’s formidable record at home, the company’s recent setbacks have exposed a rare vulnerability overseas.
articles.abstract: Given Wal-Mart’s formidable record at home, the company’s recent setbacks have exposed a rare vulnerability overseas.
articles.lead_paragraph: WIESBADEN, Germany, July 31 — Three days after Wal-Mart Stores announced that it would pull out of Germany, Roland Kögel was wandering through the aisles of a somewhat threadbare Wal-Mart in a strip mall in this western German city.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Postal Service Finds a Friend in the Internet
articles.snippet: At a recent conference that attracted 15,000 eBay fanatics to Las Vegas, the main sponsor was a big advocate of online shopping: none other than the United States Postal Service.     ''I have one message today for the entire eBay community,'' said...
articles.abstract: At a recent conference that attracted 15,000 eBay fanatics to Las Vegas, the main sponsor was a big advocate of online shopping: none other than the United States Postal Service.     ''I have one message today for the entire eBay community,'' said Postmaster General John E. Potter in a speech to the crowd. ''We, the Postal Service, we love you. We love every buyer, every seller, every power seller. Thank you for shipping with the United States Postal Service.''
articles.lead_paragraph: At a recent conference that attracted 15,000 eBay fanatics to Las Vegas, the main sponsor was a big advocate of online shopping: none other than the United States Postal Service.

articles.headline: These Days, Wall Street Does It All
articles.snippet: Follow the money.      That has been the mantra on Wall Street for years, and it is now taking financial firms deep into private equity and hedge funds.     But in that pursuit, the lines have sometimes blurred among hedge funds, private equity fi...
articles.abstract: Follow the money.      That has been the mantra on Wall Street for years, and it is now taking financial firms deep into private equity and hedge funds.     But in that pursuit, the lines have sometimes blurred among hedge funds, private equity firms and investment banks. Wall Street firms are rushing into private equity, but to avoid any appearance of conflict, some are tying themselves in knots to make clear they will not compete with clients, just co-invest with them.

articles.headline: Washington Traffic Jam? Senators-Only Elevator
articles.snippet: In addition to lofty issues of war and peace, the Senate is grappling with another urgent matter: the senators-only elevators at the Capitol are being overrun by the unelected.     ''I hesitate to say that it's a big problem,'' said Senator Frank ...
articles.abstract: In addition to lofty issues of war and peace, the Senate is grappling with another urgent matter: the senators-only elevators at the Capitol are being overrun by the unelected.     ''I hesitate to say that it's a big problem,'' said Senator Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey, shaking his head gravely. ''There is terrific crowding.''
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 30 - In addition to lofty issues of war and peace, the Senate is grappling with another urgent matter: the senators-only elevators at the Capitol are being overrun by the unelected.

articles.headline: A New Page in the Script for Paulson
articles.snippet: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., delivering his first public remarks since taking office last month, said yesterday that he recognized that the economy was not benefiting all Americans.     ''Amid this country's strong economic expansion, ...
articles.abstract: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., delivering his first public remarks since taking office last month, said yesterday that he recognized that the economy was not benefiting all Americans.     ''Amid this country's strong economic expansion, many Americans simply aren't feeling the benefits,'' Mr. Paulson said in a speech at Columbia Business School on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. ''Many aren't seeing significant increases in their take-home pay. Their increases in wages are being eaten up by high energy prices and rising health care costs, among others.''
articles.lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., delivering his first public remarks since taking office last month, said yesterday that he recognized that the economy was not benefiting all Americans.

articles.headline: Castro Is Stable, but His Illness Presents Puzzle
articles.snippet: Cuba was wrapped in uncertainty on Tuesday, as the Communist government released a statement suggesting that its longtime ruler, Fidel Castro, had survived intestinal surgery but giving few details of his condition.     After a long day of specula...
articles.abstract: Cuba was wrapped in uncertainty on Tuesday, as the Communist government released a statement suggesting that its longtime ruler, Fidel Castro, had survived intestinal surgery but giving few details of his condition.     After a long day of speculation and rumor, an announcer on state-run television and radio said he had spoken to Mr. Castro and read a statement that he said had been written by the Cuban leader, who will be 80 on Aug. 13. In the statement, Mr. Castro said that his condition was stable but that the full extent of his illness would not be known for several days.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Finds That Its Formula Doesnt Fit Every Culture
articles.snippet: Three days after Wal-Mart Stores announced that it would pull out of Germany, Roland Kögel was wandering through the aisles of a somewhat threadbare Wal-Mart in a strip mall in this western German city.     ''Why are they giving up now?'' he asked...
articles.abstract: Three days after Wal-Mart Stores announced that it would pull out of Germany, Roland Kögel was wandering through the aisles of a somewhat threadbare Wal-Mart in a strip mall in this western German city.     ''Why are they giving up now?'' he asked. ''They have good prices and a good variety of products.''
articles.lead_paragraph: WIESBADEN, Germany, July 31 - Three days after Wal-Mart Stores announced that it would pull out of Germany, Roland Kögel was wandering through the aisles of a somewhat threadbare Wal-Mart in a strip mall in this western German city.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Israel Expands Ground Forces Inside Lebanon
articles.snippet: Israel sent up to 7,000 troops into Lebanon on Tuesday, a significant increase in a ground offensive aimed at pushing the Hezbollah militia back from the border before a cease-fire is declared and a multinational force deployed.     The troops, ba...
articles.abstract: Israel sent up to 7,000 troops into Lebanon on Tuesday, a significant increase in a ground offensive aimed at pushing the Hezbollah militia back from the border before a cease-fire is declared and a multinational force deployed.     The troops, backed by air support, tanks and armored bulldozers, entered at four places along the border, moving up to 4.5 miles inside to engage Hezbollah fighters and destroy their outposts and structures.
articles.lead_paragraph: MISGAV AM, Israel, Wednesday, Aug. 2 - Israel sent up to 7,000 troops into Lebanon on Tuesday, a significant increase in a ground offensive aimed at pushing the Hezbollah militia back from the border before a cease-fire is declared and a multinational force deployed.
articles.byline: By Craig S. Smith and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Anxiety Rises as Paychecks Trail Inflation
articles.snippet: LAST week, as the Chicago City Council prepared to vote on a bill that would impose a $10 minimum wage on the city's big-box retailers by 2010 and require them to pay health benefits as well, the big guns came out to defeat it.     Mayor Richard M...
articles.abstract: LAST week, as the Chicago City Council prepared to vote on a bill that would impose a $10 minimum wage on the city's big-box retailers by 2010 and require them to pay health benefits as well, the big guns came out to defeat it.     Mayor Richard M. Daley said the bill was tantamount to redlining, because it would keep stores and jobs out of black neighborhoods. Andrew Young, the 1960's civil rights leader, traveled to Chicago and chided black leaders who supported the bill. Around the city, Chicagoans could see a ''Don't Box Us Out!'' advertising campaign paid for by Wal-Mart, and editorials in both Chicago newspapers denounced the bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAST week, as the Chicago City Council prepared to vote on a bill that would impose a $10 minimum wage on the city's big-box retailers by 2010 and require them to pay health benefits as well, the big guns came out to defeat it.

articles.headline: Bushs Embrace of Israel Shows Gap With Father
articles.snippet: When they first met as United States president and Israeli prime minister, George W. Bush made clear to Ariel Sharon he would not follow in the footsteps of his father.     The first President Bush had been tough on Israel, especially the Israeli ...
articles.abstract: When they first met as United States president and Israeli prime minister, George W. Bush made clear to Ariel Sharon he would not follow in the footsteps of his father.     The first President Bush had been tough on Israel, especially the Israeli settlements in occupied lands that Mr. Sharon had helped develop. But over tea in the Oval Office that day in March 2001 -- six months before the Sept. 11 attacks tightened their bond -- the new president signaled a strong predisposition to support Israel.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 - When they first met as United States president and Israeli prime minister, George W. Bush made clear to Ariel Sharon he would not follow in the footsteps of his father.

articles.headline: Toyotas U.S. Sales Edge Past Fords
articles.snippet: The Japanese auto giant Toyota passed the struggling Ford Motor Company in July to rank as the second-biggest-selling auto company in the United States, behind General Motors, sales figures showed Tuesday.     And in another development that lifte...
articles.abstract: The Japanese auto giant Toyota passed the struggling Ford Motor Company in July to rank as the second-biggest-selling auto company in the United States, behind General Motors, sales figures showed Tuesday.     And in another development that lifted automotive eyebrows, Honda, another Japanese company, outsold DaimlerChrysler's Chrysler group last month for the first time.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Aug. 1 - The Japanese auto giant Toyota passed the struggling Ford Motor Company in July to rank as the second-biggest-selling auto company in the United States, behind General Motors, sales figures showed Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Fara Warner
